A series of vanadium catalysts with bulky bis(N-heterocyclic carbenes) (bis-NHCs) ligands were synthesized by in-situ reaction. With diethylaluminum chloride (AlEt2Cl) as cocatalyst and ethyl trichloroacetate (ETA) as activator, these catalysts exhibit good activity when used to catalyze ethylene (co)polymerization. The structure of the catalyst, especially the bridging carbons number of the bis-NHCs ligands, is related to the performance of the (co)polymer. When the bis-NHCs ligand with t Bu substituted, increased the bridging carbons number of the bis-NHCs ligand is easier to obtain higher molecular weight polymers. But when the bis-NHCs ligand with 2,6-diisopropyl phenyl substituted, the increase of the bridging carbons number is not conducive to obtaining higher molecular weight polymers. Under the same concentration of comonomer, the increase of the bis-NHCs ligand bridged carbon number of the V-complexes is more beneficial to obtain the copolymer with high norbornene (NB) content. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Bis(N-heterocyclic carbenes) ligands Vanadium (III) complexes (co)polymerization Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Vanadium-based catalysts have displayed mean activities slightly lower than the analogous catalysts of group IV metals such as titanium and zirconium, but display several characteristic advantages including producing ultra-high molecular weight polyethylenes (UHMWPE) with controllable molecular weight distributions (Đ) and achieving copolymers with a high-ratio of comonomer incorporation [1,2]. To tailor polyolefins in order to design their microstructures, there are more and more studies on post-metallocene vanadium (III-V) catalysts employing various N- [3–5], O- [6–8], S- [9], P- [10] and even N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands[11–13]. Among them, due to the balanced catalytic activity and stability of bidentate vanadium (III) complexes, it is the focus of current research. NHCs have become established as efficient ancillary ligands for homogeneous catalysis, and over the past decades, an increasing number of catalytic transformations have been carried out using these transition-metal carbene complexes [14]. Following the success of their monodentate analogues, chelating bis(N-heterocyclic carbenes) (bis-NHCs) have become popular ligands in transition metal catalysis [15]. Because of the chelate effect these bis-NHCs lead to metal complexes with higher stability compared to their monodentate NHC counterparts. Bis-NHCs have been coordinated to many transition metals: ruthenium [16], rhodium [17], iridium [18], palladium[19,20], platinum [21], nickel [22] and iron [23]. ( Fig. 1). Generally, the ligand with large steric hindrance is helpful to inhibit the chain transfer reaction, so it is beneficial to obtain higher molecular weight polymers [24]. In this paper, we are interested in the synthesis of vanadium (III) complexes with bulky bis-NHCs ligands via in-situ reactions and their catalytic capabilities toward ethylene (co)polymerization in combination with AlEt2Cl and ethyl trichloroacetate (ETA). 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Toluene was distilled from Na under nitrogen. AlEt2Cl, Ethyl trichloroacetate (ETA), Ag2O, and VCl3(THF)3 were purchased from Innochem. Norbornene was purified by distillation under nitrogen and used as a solution in toluene. All other chemical reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and used without purification. 2.2 Measurement 1H NMR spectra and 13C NMR spectra of ligands were carried out on a Bruker 400 MHz at room temperature in DMSO-d6.13C NMR spectra of polymers were carried out on a Bruker 500 MHz at 100 °C in C2D2Cl4 or C6D4Cl2. Molecular weight (M w ) and molecular weight distribution (Đ) were measured by a Polychar GPC-IR high-temperature size exclusion chromatography equipped jointly with an infrared detector and a viscosity detector. The polymer samples were dissolved in 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene at 1.0 mg/mL. The measurement was performed with a fluent flow rate of 1.0 mL/min at 170 °C. Crystallization behaviors of the polymer samples were measured by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) on a Pyris 1 PerkinElmer instrument under a flowing nitrogen atmosphere. The specimens were first fast heated to 240 °C and held at that temperature for 3 min to ensure complete melting, then cooled to − 50 °C at 10 °C/min, and heated again to 240 °C at the same rate. The cooling and the second heating profiles were recorded, from where data of melting temperature (T m ), fusion enthalpy (ΔH m ), and crystallization temperature (T c ) were collected. MALDI–TOF-MS: The reaction solutions of the situ reactions as sample were analyzed by MALDI–TOF-MS (AutoFlex III, Bruker, America) with a 337 nm nitrogen laser for ionization. 10–15 mg of 100% THF and 0.1% TFA mixed solution was used as a matrix solution. The mixture (1 μL) of sample and matrix was placed on the sample target and dried at room temperature. 2.3 Synthesis of the bulky bis-NHCs pre-ligands The bulky bis-NHCs pre-ligands were prepared according to the previously reported[25] procedure with some modifications. In a typical example, the pre-ligands were carried out as follows ( Fig. 2). Step 1: To a solution of imidazole (30.0 mmol) in acetonitrile (10 mL) in an ACE pressure tube, (CH2)xBr2 ( 15.0 mmol) was added. A colorless precipitate formed after the solution had been heated at 130 °C for 24 h. The precipitate was filtered and washed with THF (3 × 10 mL). A colorless powder was obtained after the product had been dried in vacuo. Step 2: Compound 1 (0.3 mmol) and Ag2O (0.5 mmol) were added to a Schlenk tube. The mixture was degassed and added MeCN (20 mL) with a syringe, which was stirred with exclusion of light for 24 h at 50 ℃. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting solution was filtered and concentrated to 5 mL, then Et2O (30 mL) was added to precipitate a pale white powder. The experimental detail was shown in Supporting. HRMS (ESI) Calculated for C66H88N8Ag2 [M-2Br]2+ 604.2615, found 604.2615. 2.4 Homopolymerization of ethylene The vanadium complexes were prepared in-site as follows: Under N2 condition, 5 μmol VCl3(THF)3 and 2.5 μmol the bulky bis-NHCs pre-ligands mixed in dichloromethane (2 mL) and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. The reaction mixture was directly used for polymerization without any separation and purification. Polymerizations were carried out in a 500 mL high pressure reactor. Before polymerization, the reactor was heated under vacuum and equilibrated the pressure with nitrogen. Then the reactor was charged via syringe with 250 mL toluene, the prescribed amount of AlEt2Cl, ETA and vanadium complex. The system was maintained by continuously stirring for 1 min. With the ethylene added, the polymerization begins. During the reaction, the pressure of ethylene was kept constant. After 30 min the ethylene supply was closed and the reaction vessel was vented. The product was washed with methanol, then dried under reduced pressure at 55 °C for 6 h to a constant weight. 2.5 Copolymerization of ethylene with norbornene Before polymerization, a 500 mL high pressure reactor was heated under vacuum and equilibrated the pressure with nitrogen. The reactor was charged with 180 mL toluene, the prescribed amount of AlEt2Cl, ETA, and vanadium complex. The system was maintained by continuously stirring for 1 min, and then the norbornene was charged into the reactor. The pressure was maintained by continuously feeding ethylene gas and the reaction was carried out for 30 min. Polymerization was terminated by the addition of acidic ethanol. The resulting precipitated polymers were collected and treated by filtering, washing with ethanol several times, and drying under vacuum at 55 ℃ to a constant weight. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Optimization of polymerization conditions The vanadium (III) catalysts were obtained by the metal exchange reaction of V and Ag through in-situ reactions. In this part, 2b was used as the bulky bis-NHCs pre-ligand to prepare vanadium (III) catalyst and optimize polymerization conditions. As shown in Table 1, the ethylene slurry polymerization with AlEt2Cl as cocatalyst and ETA as activator were carried out at 0.5 MPa. The influences of the Al/V molar ratio and temperature on reactivity were studied. The activity of the catalyst increases first and then decreases with the increase of AlEt2Cl addition. When the Al/V ratio is 1000, the catalyst has the best catalytic activity (Table 1, entry 1–3). Under these conditions, reducing the reaction temperature is unfavorable to the catalytic activity. The activity can reach 107 (g PE/mol V/h) when the temperature is increased to 70 °C, but it decreases significantly when the reaction temperature is further increased to 90 °C (Table 1, entry 4–7), which can be explained as the vanadium (III) catalyst decomposition and lower ethylene solubility in toluene at a higher temperature. 3.2 Ethylene polymerization catalyzed by vanadium complexes All the vanadium complexes were used to catalyze ethylene polymerization under the optimum conditions and the experimental results are shown in Table 2. As you can see, all vanadium complexes with or without the bulky bis-NHCs ligands showed high activity in catalytic polymerization of ethylene. Specifically, compared with the VCl3(THF)3, the catalysts with bis-NHCs ligands showed better catalytic activity and the obtained polyethylene had a larger weight average molecular weight (M w ), relatively wider molecular weight distribution (Đ) and higher crystallinity (X c )[26]. It should be noted that the molecular weight distribution coefficient of the obtained polymer is small (Đ range from 1.4 to 2.1), which indicates that the catalyst is single active center. This also means that the catalysts we synthesized through in-situ reactions are a single compound with a specific structure. Interestingly, when the bis-NHCs ligand with t Bu substituted (pre-ligand 2a, 2b and 2c), increased the bridging carbons number of the bis-NHCs ligand is easier to obtain higher molecular weight polymers (Table 2, entry 9–11). But when the bis-NHCs ligand with 2,6-diisopropyl phenyl substituted (pre-ligand 2d, 2e and 2 f), the results might turn out to be just the opposite, the increase of the linker length is not conducive to obtaining higher molecular weight polymers (Table 2, entry 12–14). 3.3 Ethylene-Norbornene copolymerization catalyzed by vanadium complexes Ethylene-Norbornene copolymerization catalyzed by vanadium complexes was carry out under the optimum conditions and the experimental results are shown in Table 3. As you can see, the activity of the vanadium complexes with or without the bulky bis-NHCs ligand 2c decreased significantly due to the addition of NB. When the addition of NB is small (for example, 60 mmol), the molecular weight of the prepared polymer can be effectively maintained (Table 3, entry 18), and even higher molecular weight polymer can be obtained (Table 3, entry 15). However, when the amount of NB is large (for example, 120 mmol or 180 mmol), the molecular weight of the copolymer decreases significantly. The obtained copolymer still has a narrow molecular weight distribution coefficient (Đ range from 1.5 to 2.4). With the increase of NB concentration in the polymerization system, the content of NB segment in the obtained copolymer increased, the copolymer changed from crystalline polymer to amorphous polymer, the melting point (T m ) of the copolymer disappeared, and the glass transition temperature (T g ) increased. As the Table 3 shown, the copolymers of entry 16 and 19 having similar polymerization condition, Mw, Đ and NB content. The microstructure of copolymerization products was further analyzed. The 13C NMR spectra of E/NB copolymers obtained by entry 16 and 19 were shown in Fig. 3. The signals of each chemical shift region are assigned, as follows: I CH2, I C7, I C1-C4, and I C2-C3 are the total peak areas in the ranges 26–30, 30–36, 34–42, and 43–54 ppm [27]. Compared to ligand-free, the vanadium complexes with 2c as pre-ligand had stronger signal of alternating sequences. So the presence of pre-ligand makes the norbornene units more evenly dispersed in the polymer chain. It is well known that the comonomer (just like NB) concentration and the affinity between the comonomer and the catalyst jointly determine the insertion amount of the comonomer in the copolymer. When the content of NB in the polymerization reaction system is low, the affinity between NB and catalyst determines the content of NB segment in the copolymer. It is worth noting that under the condition of the same amount and low concentration of NB, the vanadium complexes with 2c as pre-ligand had a higher content of NB in the copolymer obtained by catalytic polymerization compared with the vanadium complexes without ligand (entry 15 vs. 18 and entry 16 vs. 19). The experimental results indicate that the VCl3 with 2c as pre-ligand has better NB affinity than VCl3(THF)3. 3.4 Effects of bulky bis-NHCs pre-ligand of the V-complexes on E/NB copolymer To explore the influence of the bulky bis-NHCs pre-ligand structure of the V-complexes on copolymer composition, E/NB copolymerization experiments at low NB concentration were carried out and the experimental results are shown in Table 4. Under the same amount of NB, the V-complexes with different bis-NHCs ligands showed similar catalytic activity, and the obtained polymers had similar Mw and Đ. It is not difficult to find that there is a regularity between the number of bridged carbon in the catalyst ligand and the content of NB in the copolymer. The increase of the bis-NHCs ligand bridged carbon number of the V-complexes is more beneficial to obtain the copolymer with high NB content. The 13C NMR spectra of E/NB copolymers obtained by entry 24, 25 and 26 were shown in Fig. 4. The copolymers are practically atactic with only a slight excess of the syndiotactic alternating sequences. With the increase of the bridged carbon number, as shown in Fig. 3, the signal areas of isolated norbornene sequences are improved. Meanwhile, the alternating isotactic sequences are also enhanced. 3.5 Structure analysis of the vanadium complexes To explain the above experimental results from the perspective of the vanadium catalyst, a series of analysis tests to determine the possible molecular structure of the vanadium catalyst were carry out. Because the synthesis of each catalyst molecule is accompanied by the formation of two molecules of AgBr (very difficult to separate), we failed to obtain the crystal structure of the catalyst. In addition, V(III) is easy to coordinate with nitrogen, oxygen and other heteroatoms in the system, resulting in our inability to obtain a relatively clear NMR spectrum. Fortunately, the MALDI-TOF-MS spectrum of the catalyst provides some important information ( Table 5). Based on the existing literature reports and mass spectrometry data analysis, we speculate that the possible structure of the catalyst was shown in Table 5. The single active center catalyst with specific structure explained that the obtained polymers showed a narrow molecular weight distribution. Compared with the catalyst 3d, 3e and 3f, with the increase of the bridged carbon number, the steric hindrance of the V active center decreases, which is more conducive to the insertion of the large steric hindrance comonomer. This also explains that under the same concentration of comonomer, the catalyst 3 f can obtain the copolymer with higher NB insertion amount. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of vanadium (III) complexes with bulky bis-NHCs ligand has been synthesized via in-situ reactions. In ethylene homopolymerization, compared with VCl3(THF)3, the vanadium (Ⅲ) complexes with bis-NHCs ligand showed good catalytic activity, and the obtained polyethylene had a larger M w , relatively wider Đ and higher X c . In E/NB copolymerization, the addition of norbornene significantly decreased the activity. With the increase of the concentration of NB, the content of the norbornene chain in the obtained copolymer increased gradually. What is more important, relationships were found to exist between the catalyst structure and the catalytic performance. When the bis-NHCs ligand with t Bu substituted, increased the bridging carbons number of the bis-NHCs ligand is easier to obtain higher molecular weight polymers. But when the bis-NHCs ligand with 2,6-diisopropyl phenyl substituted, the increase of the linker length is not conducive to obtaining higher molecular weight polymers. Under the same concentration of comonomer, the increase of the bis-NHCs ligand bridged carbon number of the V-complexes is more beneficial to obtain the copolymer with high NB content. Finally, the possible structure of the catalyst was proposed and the polymerization behaviors were explained. coredata.dc:description: A series of vanadium catalysts with bulky bis(N-heterocyclic carbenes) (bis-NHCs) ligands were synthesized by in-situ reaction. With diethylaluminum chloride (AlEt2Cl) as cocatalyst and ethyl trichloroacetate (ETA) as activator, these catalysts exhibit good activity when used to catalyze ethylene (co)polymerization. The structure of the catalyst, especially the bridging carbons number of the bis-NHCs ligands, is related to the performance of the (co)polymer. When the bis-NHCs ligand with t Bu substituted, increased the bridging carbons number of the bis-NHCs ligand is easier to obtain higher molecular weight polymers. But when the bis-NHCs ligand with 2,6-diisopropyl phenyl substituted, the increase of the bridging carbons number is not conducive to obtaining higher molecular weight polymers. Under the same concentration of comonomer, the increase of the bis-NHCs ligand bridged carbon number of the V-complexes is more beneficial to obtain the copolymer with high norbornene (NB) content.
coredata.dc:title: Vanadium (III) catalysts with bulky Bis-NHCs ligands for ethylene-norbornene (co)polymerization
